ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Lots of practice with models and considering the built environment
I learned how to think critically and differently about many situations and given a lot of open responses to questions.
My thought processes and conceptualization of space was pushed. My drawing skills increased and my ability to use architectural terms in presentations became better.

So much- greatly improved technical skills in drawing, rhino, model making (specifically with wood). Also just general approaches to design, how to break things down into elements as a starting point, learnt a lot about my own working process
Design thinking, design voice, design theory, design practice, making practice, critique environment and knowledge, technical skills in adobe suite, woodworking, drawing, and presentation.
applying previously learned architectural principals like plan, section, elevation, proper documentation of projects, architectural thinking and project iteration.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The class overall a great experience. I have two complaints:

The critics who come in for mid and final review usually  don't know our project prompts until the hour of, so they often give useless comments like "maybe you could have tried this", which would be helpful in the initial stages of the project, but after having decided the theme and worked hard on a project, receiving comments on how to improve what is ACTUALLY being presented would be much more helpful. Also, I wish they would do a "how to present an architecture project" workshop because even if you have a great project, if you don't present it well the idea is lost.

The class budget of $200 seems like a lot, but once you go through weekly crits of printing costs of $15+, the money is gone instantly. Reimbursement for the course is also a pain, receiving petty cash would probably be more effective, since everyone uses $200+ but can't get the money they used due to difficulty of reimbursement.
This course was fantastic. Great introductory course into architecture.

Love the conceptual approach to the class and the teaching is incredible and really great resources provided. its very fast paced and a ton of very constant, demanding work but teaching time very accommodating 

I wish there was a way of getting feedback besides at reviews eg something at midterm to discuss progress

Strengths: broad, intellectually challenging and stimulating assignments, room to explore and pursue your own ideas.
Weaknesses: more clarity on expectations for amount of work produced. Sometimes a little vague.

Strengths: highly engaged TAs and professors, great cohort to bond with and expand architectural thinking.
Weaknesses: high workload, potentially could be trimmed down to avoid work for works sake. A lot of stress since this is the required class for the major.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes but only if they are serious about architecture. Otherwise it would not be worth the time.
Yes, I mean its required for majors but its very different from what I imagined studio to be in the best way

The most fun studio class I've ever taken, especially because of Trattie! So much room to think, learn, design, and make. Less emphasis on technical design skills and more on the intellectual arguments of your work. Great cohort of students that worked, learned, and hung out together in the studio for many hours a week.

It is a course required for the architecture major, though I wouldn't recommend for anyone who isn't in architecture. Be prepared to spend a lot of time on the projects (thinking, drawing, 3D modeling, photography, etc.). It is a course that pushed me and I grew a lot, but definitely experienced a lot of stress in the process.
